node.title: Environment Ministry considers national database to register old landfill sites
node.description: The Ministry for the Environment is considering creating a national database and fund to protect vulnerable old landfill sites.

node.title: Two teens still in hospital a month after shooting in Invercargill
node.description: There are still no arrests over the shooting of two teenagers in Invercargill a month on.

node.title: Police, hapū and iwi monitoring anti-mandate protest in New Plymouth
node.description: No decision has been made whether to trespass anti-vaccination madate protesters camped on reserve land in New Plymouth.

node.title: Photo essay: Russia's invasion of Ukraine
node.description: The Russian attack on its neighbour Ukraine has shocked the world this week. Here are some of the most dramatic images of the conflict and protests around the world against it.

node.title: High warrant failure rate must be addressed to help cut road toll - MTA
node.description: The Motor Trade Association says Waka Kotahi needs to do more to improve the state of vehicles on New Zealand's roads. Audio

node.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene downplays speaking at a conference founded by white nationalist
node.description: Republicans have criticized Greene's attendance, though some have ignored or claimed they didn't know about it.

node.title: Decisions on border restrictions to be discussed today - PM
node.description: Tensions are simmering over the government's response to events both domestic and international, Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern speaks to Morning Report.

node.title: The town that backed a child sex abuser
node.description: When a firefighter abused his young son, many in their small town refused to believe it. Fire and Emergency kept him on, and locals turned on the boy's mum, saying she'd made up the allegations.

node.title: Govt under more pressure to ease border restrictions as Covid cases rise
node.description: Political pressure is mounting on the government to move faster on easing border restrictions as the domestic outbreak escalates.

node.title: Officers stood down over mandates seen protesting at Parliament - Police association
node.description: Police will have to consider what work returning officers do as some stood down over vaccine mandates may have been protesters at Parliament, the police association says. Audio

node.title: 'Nobody is above the law': Mayor says council ready to act on protesters
node.description: Auckland Mayor Phil Goff says council has trespass orders "ready to go" as Auckland Domain remains closed to vehicles due to a small number of protesters refusing to leave. Audio

node.title: Former PM Jim Bolger worries Russia invasion will not stop with Ukraine
node.description: Former prime minister Jim Bolger is fearful Russian President Vladimir Putin will try to invade other former Soviet states after Ukraine, in an attempt to restore the Soviet Union.

node.title: Zelensky: The comedian president who is rising to the moment
node.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, a comedian new to politics when elected three years ago, has suddenly emerged as a convincing war leader.

node.title: New York governor says school mask mandate will end Wednesday
node.description: New York City's indoor vaccine mandate could end by March 7, the mayor said.

node.title: Restaurant Brands' net profit expands by about $21m
node.description: Fast food retailing group Restaurant Brands has seen an increase in net profit, despite the ongoing challenges on the hospitality sector from Covid-19.

node.title: 2degrees launches 5G network
node.description: From today, 5G connectivity will be available to certain customers in central areas of Auckland and Wellington, as well as limited parts of Christchurch.

node.title: Ukrainian oil, gas facilities burn as West prepares new sanctions
node.description: Russian forces have attacked oil and gas facilities in Ukraine, sparking huge explosions, officials said on Sunday, as Western allies prepared new sanctions.

node.title: Americans unjustly held abroad by foreign governments
node.description: The vast majority of Americans wrongfully imprisoned abroad today are not held by terrorist groups, but by foreign governments. Lesley Stahl reports.

node.title: 'A lot more certainty' for Chatham Islands with tourism spike
node.description: With borders closed, more New Zealanders have been ticking the Chatham Islands off their bucket list than before the pandemic.

node.title: Danny Fenster on life inside Myanmar's notorious Insein Prison
node.description: The American journalist was held captive in Myanmar for almost six months. He told 60 Minutes what his days were like inside the infamous lockup known for holding political prisoners.

node.title: U.S. electric grid faces Russian and domestic threats
node.description: Bill Whitaker reports that a coordinated attack on a relatively small number of critical substations could plunge the U.S. into darkness.

node.title: Te Kahu o te Raukura laid as a cloak of peace over Parliament grounds and ancestral whenua
node.description: Before the sun rose - descendants of Taranaki Whanui and its leaders in Wellington gathered at Pipitea Marae - just down the road from the protest - to lay te Kahu o te Raukura on its whenua as a…

node.title: T&G Global full year profit down 20 percent
node.description: The business faced significant challenges over the past year, with supply chain disruptions, missed sales opportunities, bad weather and labour shortages.

node.title: Fonterra suspends shipments to Russia
node.description: Dairy company Fonterra has suspended shipments of its products to Russia.

node.title: Lawyer 'extremely concerned' for healthcare of disabled after hospital visit
node.description: With thousands of new cases of Covid-19 emerging in the community everyday, there are concerns about what the surge is going to do to the already-stretched healthcare system. Audio

node.title: Covid-19 testing advice update needed to better understand rate of infections, says modeller
node.description: Relying on the current hospitalisation rate of Covid-19 cases as an indicator of future hospitalisations could be dangerous, a modeller says. Audio

node.title: Russian forces have yet to capture a city in Ukraine, U.S. defense official says
node.description: "The Ukrainians are putting up a very stiff and brave and heroic resistance, but we are only in Day Four," the senior defense official said.

node.title: Trade minister hopes to conclude FTA negotiations with EU in overseas trip
node.description: Trade Minister Damien O'Connor will embark on a trip to Europe this weekend, where he plans to underline New Zealand's expectations for a Free Trade Agreement with the European Union.

node.title: 'It's just rock bottom': Roadworks leave Shannon businesses stranded
node.description: Roadworks in Horowhenua are having a huge effect on businesses in Shannon, with some reporting drops in trade of up to 90 percent.

node.title: Legal challenge over decision that AI machines cannot be granted patents
node.description: A legal challenge is being prepared to overturn the Intellectual Property Office's decision not to recognise a machine as an inventor.
